awd_titl_txt: New Directions in High Energy Nuclear Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
Among the four fundamental forces in nature the strong nuclear force stands out for being the least understood one. It drives many processes in the universe that are crucial for our existence. One particularly important aspect of the strong nuclear force is the existence of quark gluon plasma. If ordinary matter is heated up to temperatures of about 1,000,000,000,000 degrees, hotter than the core of the sun, atoms and molecules cease to exist and even protons and neutrons inside atomic nuclei melt. The remaining primordial soup of quarks and gluons filled the very early universe. We can recreate quark gluon plasma in our largest particle colliders by smashing heavy nuclei into each other. Experimental programs at the Large Hadron Collider in Europe and the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider in the USA study the properties of quark gluon plasma. This project will support research that will improve our understanding of the formation and properties of quark gluon plasma in nuclear collisions. The PI and his collaborators will use computer simulations and advanced statistical methods to reach this goal. Funding is provided to support training for a graduate students and junior scientists in nuclear science.

Quark gluon plasma in nuclear collisions emerges from the highly complex gluon fields that are initially created in nuclear collisions. The PI and his group will investigate these fields and their properties by studying how angular momentum of the droplets of quark gluon plasma is related to the initial angular momentum of the colliding nuclei. The same gluon fields will also be studied through their interaction with fast quarks. The PI and his group will be able to use the JETSCAPE framework for large scale computational simulations of nuclear collisions. They will study various aspects of jets and heavy quarks being quenched in quark gluon plasma. They will then extract properties of quark gluon plasma using multiple constraints. For example,  the strength of quenching of quarks and heavy quarks, and the viscosity of quark gluon plasma can be independently measured and are mutually related. Testing these relations will be an important step towards a deeper understanding of the dynamics of quark gluon plasma. The PI and his group will also use advanced statistical methods and machine learning applied to data to understand the mechanisms of hadron formation from quarks and gluons. These results will be used to improve the state-of-the-art modeling of the hadronization process that is a crucial input to many calculations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
High energy collisions of heavy nuclei can be studied at the most powerful particle accelerators, like the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) and the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC). For a very short amount of time they produce quark gluon plasma (QGP), very hot and dense nuclear matter which was the predominant matter in the very early Universe. With the support from this grant we have investigated several aspects of high energy nuclear collisions as part of a larger effort of the scientific community to accurately understand the dynamics of these collisions, and to study to properties of quark gluon plasma.

We have investigated the very earliest stage of nucleus-nucleus collisions. At very high energy this stage is dominated by the overlap of the gluon fields of the two nuclei. Gluons are the force carriers of the strong nuclear force. We have computed the energy density and pressure of the gluon matter created by the overlap of the gluons of the individual nuclei. It is from this gluon matter left after the collision, sometimes referred to as "glasma", that quark gluon plasma eventually emerges. The precise process of evolution from glasma to QGP is not yet understood. However, our calculation fixes important initial properties for this glasma phase, which can be used for further studies. We have also investigated futher consequences of the glasma phase, e.g. the motion of the nuclei (or their debris) after the collision, and the fate of high energy quarks and gluons that traverse the glasma.

A second project involved an important process rather late in the timeline of colliding nuclei. While quarks and gluons are initially freed in the collision, e.g. to form QGP, they eventually need to again form hadrons, i.e. colorless bound states. This is because of a unique property of the strong nuclear force which exhibits confinement. Quarks and gluons (particles with "color" charges) can not be observed in isolation. They must form bound states in which color charges combine to form a color neutral state, called a hadron. Protons, neutrons and pions are examples of such hadrons. Even if we want to study QGP we must understand this "hadronization" process well enough, because all quark and gluons turn into hadrons before they can be measured in detectors. Hadronization is a very difficult topic that still awaits its final solution. We have developed a working model called Hybrid Hadronization which combines two models that have had a successful history by themselves, string fragmentation and quark recombination. By combining them into one self-consistently implemented model, we hope to describe all possible collision systems consistently from electron-positron to nucleus-nucleus collisions. We have made several notable improvements to Hybrid Hadronization, in particular with respect to the treatment of the color charges of quarks and gluons, and the implementation of excited meson states, i.e. unstable cousins of the pion and kaon, which decay quickly but are nevertheless important in include into calculations. We have also studied the performance of Hybrid hadronization when compared to data from several collision systems. As a result we now have a rather reliable description of hadronization at our disposal.

We have also investigated one particular probe of QGP in high energy nuclear collisions, sprays of hadrons called QCD jets. They originate from single, very high energy quarks or gluons which are produced in the initial collisions of nuclei. It is of great interest to study the behavior of these quarks and gluons as they move through QGP. They will scatter with QGP particles, and they will additionally emit gluon radiation while they do so. This creates a so-called parton shower, which then becomes the collimated spray of hadrons described earlier. The latter is what is seen in detectors, so one would like to know if it is possible to reconstruct the history of the original parton shower from the observed final hadrons. Such knowledge would make this probe of QGP even more powerful. Our studies show that one can be partially successful, but some elements of the shower history are obscured by hadronization. When gluons are radiated, information on the angles of the radiation are preserves rather well, while the fractions of energy carried by the radiation and the original quark or gluon are difficult to reconstruct once hadronization has occurred. Our study can inform future attempts to reconstruct the space-time history of jets.

Lastly, we have extracted estimates for the specific shear viscosity of hadron matter from data. Besides QGP, nuclear collisons are also probing lower temperatures where a liquid of hadrons is formed. The shear viscosity as a function of temperature is shown in the figure. Note that a temperature T=0.16 GeV, roughly the transition between QGP and hadrons, corresponds to about 2 trillion degrees. This is the first determination of hadron viscosity from data.
